ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HDB WAITING LIST FOR RENTAL FLATS
(Particulars)


    1. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for National Development (a) how many persons were waiting to occupy rental flats as at 1st March, 1984; (b) the total number of flats available for rental; (c) how many of these were vacant as at 1st March, 1984 and available for applicants; and (d) how long does he estimate that an applicant for a rental flat will have to wait before he is allocated a flat.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): As at 1st March, 1984, the waiting list for Housing and Development Board rental flats has 15,660 applicants.

    There is a total of 126,564 units of rental flats under the HDB's management.

    The number of vacant units as at 1st March 1984 is 2,032. Of these, 1,117 units have been offered to applicants and are awaiting acceptance. The remaining 915 units are in the process of being allocated.

    As the HDB has stopped constructing new flats for rental, the availability of rental flats depends entirely on vacancies from tenancy terminations of existing flats. Based on recent trends in tenancy terminations, the waiting period for one-room rental flats is two years whilst that for two-room rental flats is about 4 1/2 years. The waiting period for three-room rental flats is between eight and 10 years. Applicants on the rental waiting list, especially those applying for two-room and three-room units, are urged to switch to the sales register where they can be sure of a flat within a shorter waiting period.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question for the Minister. The Minister says that applicants are advised to switch to the sales register. Is the Minister aware that in many many cases, these applicants are unable to purchase their own flats? What does the Housing and Development Board expect these persons who cannot afford to pur-

Column: 892

chase HDB flats to do when they are evicted or they find themselves without any house to live in in Singapore? Is it not the duty of the Ministry to try and house these people?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: The Member for Anson has the wrong concept of the Income of Singaporeans. I will give him statistics of the income of the 16,000 applicants on the waiting list. Those who have applied for one-room flats, have an average income of $473 per month. For those who have applied for two-room flats, it is $518 and for three-room flats, it is $603. All these applicants are in the position to purchase flats.

    I will give him the calculation so that he can understand it. The one-room applicant has an average income of $473 per month. The CPF contribution, i.e. 40%, will give him $189.20 per month. The down payment for a three-room HDB flat in a New Town, i.e. Woodlands or Yishun, is $6,600 which means that the applicant needs 35 months to accumulate sufficient CPF savings to pay for the down payment. By using his CPF savings alone, he will in 35 months have enough to pay for the 20% down payment without having to suffer any cut in take-home pay.

    The selling price of a new three-room flat in the New Town is $29,600. Therefore, after deducting the 20% down payment, he needs a loan of $23,000 from the HDB. He needs to pay only $171 per month as monthly instalment to the HDB for the purchase of a three-room flat. As I have sold earlier, he will have a CPF contribution of $189.20 per month. In other words, his CPF contribution is sufficient to pay for the monthly instalments. This applies to people who are presently waiting to rent one-room flats.

    So the Member's information that there are a lot of poor people who cannot afford this and cannot afford that, it exists only in his imagination.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question. These figures are all very good on paper. Does the Minister really expect these families to spend all their savings in CPF on the purchase of three-room flats? And what are they left with to live when they retire?

Column: 893



     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, I think the hon. Member for Anson has got it all mixed up. He cannot use his CPF money for anything else other than for the purchase of HDB flat. Buying an HDB flat is a good investment. If he purchases a three-room HDB flat now, as time goes on the value of the HDB flat will appreciate. If the hon. Member has read the advertisements today in the Straits Times or asks his Party members to look up the Chinese newspapers, he will see the selling prices. After five years' occupation of an HDB flat, a person can sell his HDB fiat and make a handsome profit. So by purchasing an HDB flat, he does not only have a home, a nice home in a nice estate, but also a good investment.

     Mr Jeyaretnam : Is the Minister seriously suggesting that these people earning $470 or above should spend 90% of all their CPF monies every month for the purchase of a flat and then five years later they should sell them? Where are they going to live after that? Or that they can sell the flat when they stop working. Where are they going to live? What is going to happen to their families? Who is going to look after them? Can the Minister answer all these questions?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the hon. Member really does not know what is going on in Singapore. The HDB can supply him with a lot of information. After five years, if a person sells his flat he can go on to a bigger flat because the income of Singaporeans is constantly being improved. The people are moving from the smaller flats to the bigger flats all the time. I can supply him with information on the number of one-room tenants living in HDB flats who are waiting to buy bigger flats. I can supply him with a whole set of information, to show that the income of Singaporeans is constantly being improved and they are living in bigger and better flats.

    From the information on the present waiting list, the people who are waiting to rent HDB flats as I have given him earlier is 16,000. And the number of people who are waiting to buy HDB flats is more than 90,000. So these figures will tell you that the income of Singaporeans is continually being improved. The Member is imagining

Column: 894

that poor people are crawling around in Singapore, that people have no homes, that people are in a miserable condition. It - is just not true.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Supplementary question, Mr Speaker, Sir. Is it not true that many Housing Board dwellers who have bought their flats are able to rent out one or two rooms, especially those who live in four-room and five-room flats? Therefore, they can derive quits an income from the rental.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is true that the HDB allows tenants to sublet their flats. For the three-room flats, they are allowed to sublet one bedroom, and for four-room flats, they are allowed to sublet two bedrooms. But I think the majority of Singaporeans do not wish to sublet their rooms even though the number of their family members may be small. They prefer to use those rooms as a study room, as their children's playroom or for other uses. In fact, they are very unwilling to sublet. This is an indication that the income of Singaporeans is so comfortable that they prefer not to sublet rooms even if they can get a very handsome rental.

TREE CUTTING IN UNIVERSITY GROUNDS


    2. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Finance and Minister for Trade and Industry if he will ascertain from the National University of Singapore the reason for the cuffing down of trees in the University grounds before the recent visit of the Prime Minister to the campus.

     The Minister for Finance and Minister for Trade and Industry (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam): Mr Speaker, Sir, the National University of Singapore cuts down trees when they are old, brittle or unsightly. The NUS also plants new trees and shrubs when necessary. All this is part of a continuing process to upgrade and improve the environment and landscape of the campus grounds and not, as implied by the Member for Anson's question, a special effort to beautify the grounds for the Prime Minister's visit.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Sir, are we to understand from the Hon. Minister's reply that

Column: 895

the NUS suddenly discovered before the Prime Minister visited the University that a lot of the trees were rotten and unsightly?

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Mr Speaker, Sir, evidently the Member has not listened to my answer. If the University were to cut down trees every time the Prime Minister visits it, then the campus will resemble a desert. I can assure the Member that there are many trees left in the campus.

MAIN AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES
OF SINGAPORE FOR THE FINANCIAL

YEAR 1ST APRIL, 1984 TO 31ST MARCH, 1985

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]


2.45 pm

     The Chairman: Main and Development Estimates of Singapore for the financial year 1st April, 1984 to 31st March, 1985, contained in Paper Cmd. 5 of 1984. For convenience, I shall take the totals for each head of expenditure in the Main and Development Estimates as they appear in the last columns of the schedules of Estimated Expenditure under the Main and Development Estimates on pages 17 and 18, respectively, of Paper Cmd. 5 of 1984.

    I shall deal first with the heads of expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper Supplement.

    Head U -

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head U be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead UA-01 of the Main Estimates.

Column: 896



    Mr Speaker, Sir, this is the vote for the Administration programme of the Prime Minister's Office and, as you will see in the Budget, the objective is to coordinate activities of the Ministries and the general policies of the Government. It is on a matter concerning the policy of the Government that I am moving this amendment, Mr Speaker, Sir, and that is the accountability of the Government and the various Ministries to the citizens and residents in Singapore.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, on the 3rd December, 1982, I asked the Prime Minister a question as to whether he would consider directing all Ministries that in cases where they reject any application from a citizen or make any decision which impinges on the rights of the citizen, they should give detailed reasons for their rejection or decision. In other words, I was asking the Prime Minister whether he would direct all Ministries to account for their decision when they turn down any request from a citizen. The Prime Minister's reply was that his Government had explained its policies again and again and no other government had taken the trouble that his Government had taken and that every body understood the policy and that the rules could not be bent for anyone. And he said that if I did not understand the reason for anything, I could bring it up in this House again when I got a reply from the Ministry. Well, Mr Speaker, Sir, I have had several replies, not one, from Ministries when I take up matters on behalf of citizens concerning be it citizenship, or be it licences for various things, and the stock reply, Mr Speaker, Sir, is, "we regret that the application is not successful." I have tried to go back a number of times to ask why the application in that particular instance was not successful. And again comes the stock reply, "we have explained this before and the applicant must know." But he really does not know the reason for "we regret your application has been rejected". And so it goes on ad nauseam.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, may I give you one case in point? There is a man who lives in my constituency, and may I make it clear - he is not a citizen. He is a permanent resident but he should have got his citizenship years ago; he has been denied his citizenship. He has a family with children, and his

Column: 897

wife was asked to leave Singapore and go back to Malaysia because she happened to be a Malaysian. Well, it is not about her that I am raising this matter. It is about his son. She had taken the children away with her but later, on his request, the Immigration Department gave him permission to keep one of his sons in Singapore because the boy was not in good health and needed to be looked after in a children's home, and he had provided for this in Sembawang. But six months afterwards the Immigration Department suddenly reversed its stand and said, "No, you have got to take the boy out." And the man came to me and I appealed to the Immigration Department, and the stock reply was, "He can't. He is not eligible at all to stay here." The father is a permanent resident and he has been working here for many many years. Then I wrote to the Minister and I sent a carbon copy of it to the Prime Minister to explain the sort of reply that I was getting and would he do something about it; or would he rather that I raised it in Parliament. And the answer came back from the Prime Minister, "You raise it in Parliament." The Permanent Secretary's reply is quite clear - that this boy is not eligible to stay here. The question is why? Should the man not be told why he cannot keep his son?

    This is the sort of situation that we find ourselves in Singapore, where the citizen or the permanent resident is not told anything at all of the reasons behind any Government decision affecting his livelihood, his earnings, his stay or even the question of his applying for a passport. I can go on multiplying the instances. The Prime Minister says that the Government is accountable. He says, "we practise accountability." I should have thought that ons of the first rules of accountability is that you explain not, as a matter of general policy, broad statements but in each particular case where you deny somebody something and, where he thinks it is his right, that you explain to him why in his particular case he is not eligible for what he has asked. Mr Speaker, Sir, it is important that the Government should recognize that the citizens have rights, that they have rights to continue in their employment, in

Column: 898

their livelihood, to stay or to do whatever that a citizen is entitled to do. And if you are going to take away any of these rights or deprive him of it, then you should explain.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we have now in several countries legislation-Australia,l see, has just introduced it - the Freedom of Information Act. I think it is timely, Mr Speaker, Sir, that we considered introducing legislation on those lines which give the citizen a right to demand from the Ministries, from the Government departments, from the statutory boards, specific and detailed reasons for the rejection of any request or application made to it. Indeed, this Act, as I understand them now, go much further in some cases. It even contains the right for the citizen, for the permanent resident, to demand to see his file on which his request has been dealt with. Of course, this Act excludes matters from -

     Mr Speaker: Mr Jeyaretnam, you have used up your 10 minutes. Your time is up.

     The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, if I understand the Member for Anson, he has, from my responsibilities for coordinating Ministries, gone on to recite the instance of his constituent who is a permanent resident, whose wife had gone back to Malaysia leaving behind one ailing son, who was permitted to remain behind for compassionate reasons or whatever, in some home in Sembawang, but that permission was refused after six months and he does not know why. And he also cited that, in fact, if we were an enlightened government running enlightened policies, not only would we have a file which would be open to his constituent who is a permanent resident, but we would also introduce a Freedom of Information Act to allow all and sundry to have access to their files.

    From his recitation of the event, I do not see any lack of information. He has provided this House with all the adequate information. Every Member of this House, including those of us who have never attended meet-the-people sessions, must know that a permanent resident has not the rights, nor does he owe the State the duties of a citizen. And this gentleman who has won over the sympathy, the compas-

Column: 899

sion, and the attention of the Member for Anson, should be grateful that we have allowed him to stay in Singapore and to continue working in Singapore. We are under no obligation to keep him here or to give him a job, let alone keep a file on him or his son in order that it would be available to him or the son if we decide for, I am sure, good and valid reasons. And he would be given good and valid reasons, if he were to direct it to the appropriate Minister, why the son's permission to stay here was revoked.

    The Member for Anson is a glutton for punishment. When he first came into this House, there was a slight air of the under-dog's status. After 21 years, there is a lot of mange on the dog. I do not want to beat mangy dogs, nor do I want to get near them. The answer has been provided to the House by the Member himself. He is in full possession of the facts. I assume that this is like all the millions of other cases that he tells us he has and, obviously as a good Member of Parliament and as a good lawyer, he must have brought his strongest case forth. I expected an earth-shattering event - some misdemeanour, some misjudgment, some blunder, some outrageous act of incompetence on the part of one of my colleagues.
3.00 pm

    But I have this remarkable tribute - the impartiality with which we have administered the law, the compassion we have shown by allowing a man who is a permanent resident to have his son, who is not a citizen, six months of treatment in some Sembawang centre. What more can you ask of any government?

     The Chairman: Are you withdrawing your amendment, Mr Jeyaretnam?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: No, Sir. May I just reply to the Prime Minister since it is my motion. We have heard nothing new from the Prime Minister. We heard this the last time I raised this matter, and I expect that the next time it is raised we shall hear the same thing again.

    This man is a permanent resident but, as I said, he should have been a citizen and he is not being told why.

Column: 900



     The Prime Minister: Give me your reason why.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: What does the Constitution provide about this? If you live here for 10 years and you have got no previous conviction and you are earning a living, you may be granted a citizenship.

     Some hon. Members: "May".

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I know, "may." I know all about "may" and "shall". But why do you go on denying this man his citizenship and then his wife is forced out. If you want to know why his wife was forced out, I can tell you that as well but I am dealing with the son. He begged that the son be allowed to stay with him, and he was allowed to keep his son because his son was not well. But then six months later you suddenly say, "No". Why? What is the reason? You said that the Minister has given me the reasons. Would you like to see the reply from the Minister? The reasons have not been given. What I want to know is why is it not possible for this man to keep his son in Singapore? I do not want statements that, "We are a benevolent government. He has no right as a permanent resident." What you are saying is that nobody has any rights in this place. Is that what you are saying?

     The Prime Minister: I am saying, Mr Speaker, Sir, that the Government of Singapore is responsible for the citizens of Singapore. We have over 120,000, occasionally approximating 150,000 people, who are not citizens who work in Singapore. They are given work permits. If we adopt the attitude that has been urged upon us, we will have 120,000 to 150,000 more citizens every few years.

    There are rules and regulations made for citizenship, and I would have thought that it is the paramount duty of the Government to protect the interests of the citizens, the original members who built Singapore. If we take any lax, frivolous, so-called compassionate attitudes, those rights must be diluted. Every member of this work force who is not a citizen can become a permanent resident once he has passed certain trade tests. He can go on and apply for citizenship. If we consider him, on balance, to be a plus, to be a credit

Column: 901

to Singapore, then we give him that citizenship as a matter of privilege. There are hundreds of thousands of people who want the privilege of just coming to Singapore to work, and having got here and got work they want permanent residence. And having got permanent residence they want citizenship. That is exactly the way the Member for Anson got into Singapore. He came in first as a Malayan citizen.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: You have got it wrong.

     The Prime Minister: He is not a Singapore citizen by operation of law, by birth. He obtained his Singapore citizenship by registration. It must be, because I remember moving the laws here - the change of law in 1957 - to enable them to register themselves. And at the time that law was amended, if you look up Hansard, you will see that I strenuously protested against the unwarranted generosity of the Government who thought at that time that they were garnering votes for the next election. For every liberal foolish act, we dilute the rights of the present group of members. I do not see it as the responsibility of this Government to diminish the rights of Singapore citizens. I see it as our bounden duty to improve their prospects, improve their capacity to defend what they have and to have more and better homes, mo@e and better jobs and a better future for their children.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Does the Prime Minister not see it as amoral that you should offer citizenship to people who invest their money in this place but deny a man who has lived here for 30 years, who has worked his life in this place and has offered his loyalty to this place?

     The Prime Minister: I do not know if I need go to Machiavelli but it is the duty of every government to quietly, coolly and rationally calculate the balance of costs and benefits, the trade-offs. And if a man can come to Singapore and bring in capital, with it know-how, entrepreneurship and create the jobs as they have -

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Is that all you think of - capital?

Column: 902



     The Prime Minister: Indeed. In order that the people of Singapore can have the benefits of the equipment, the knowledge, the expertise, the capital commands.

     The Chairman: Are you going to withdraw your amendment, Mr Jeyaretnam?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: No, Sir.

    Question on the amendment put, and negatived.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head U be reduced by the whole sum in respect of Subhead UB-01 of the Main Estimates.

    Sir, this vote is for the Elections programme and I have two matters to raise under this motion. One concerns the vacancy in this House. I raised this with the Prime Minister at the sitting of this House on 20th December of last year, and this House was told by the Prime Minister that there was nothing in the Constitution that required that the vacancy should be filled and that he did not see any need for filling the vacancy because there were elections in the pipeline as it were, although he was not able to say when the elections would be held. We will wait for him to announce the elections.

    Sir, may I refer the Prime Minister to Article 49 of the Constitution. ft is quite explicit, and it says:

    'Whenever the seat of a Member has become vacant for any reason other than a dissolution, the vacancy shall [no "may" this time, Members of the House] be filled by election in the manner provided by or under any law for the time being in force in Singapore."

    I said this was amended from the Constitution that we had under the Malaysian period which required it to be filled in three months. The Prime Minister's contention was that there was no need to fill it immediately. There was no need to do anything until the general elections.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it is a rule of construction that where no time limit is stipulated in any provision in the law for the doing of any act, that act shall be done within a reasonable time. We have now gone on for about five months without a Member representing the voters of Havelock in this House. The Prime Minister was surprised when I told him that to appoint a caretaker

Column: 903

MP was to stand the principle of parliamentary representation on its head. It is, Mr Prime Minister, if you really consider it seriously because the whole idea is that the voters elect their representative into Parliament, not someone be appointed for them, like you appoint commissars in Russia or in other countries. So you are violating the whole principle of parliamentary representation, Mr Prime Minister, in having a caretaker MP for Havelock and denying the voters of Havelock their right.

    The other one, Sir, is the question of the conduct of elections. Again, if I may remind the Prime Minister, and I am sure he is aware, that in many democratic countries there is such a body known as the Elections Commission which has the responsibility to oversee and supervise the conduct of elections to Parliament. We have it in Malaysia, our nearest neighbour across the Causeway. We have it in almost all the other Commonwealth countries.

    In Singapore, Sir, way back in 1972, I remember joining with the other political parties in sending a memorandum asking for the appointment of an Elections Commission. We never got that. We did not expect it. It is now 1984 and we are still without any Elections Commission. It would appear that in Singapore elections are conducted by the Prime Minister's Department and that the Prime Minister considers the conduct of elections as his sole preserve and privilege.
3.15 pm

    I would urge upon the Prime Minister that the conduct of elections concerns not only him as the Prime Minister of this place but also concerns every citizen and it concerns every political party. It is of the utmost importance, if we claim to be a democratic society and hold democratic elections to Parliament, that the elections should be seen to be democratic, not just a statement that we are a democratic country and we hold elections democratically. It should be seen to be democratic, and the only way you can ensure this is to hand over the conduct of the elections to an independent body, an Elections Commission, where views of all political parties are sought and the composition is agreed by all the political parties. That way you show

Column: 904
